comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
The inscription on the monument reads:
To Charles Stewart Parnell
No Man has a right to fix the Boundary to the march of a nation No man has a right
To say to his country
Thus far shat thou
Go and no further
We have never
Attempted to fix
The ne-plus-ultra
To the progress of
Ireland’s nationhood
And we never shall


At the base of the statue the Irish inscription reads:
Go roimhigid Dia Éire da Clainn

The site on the corner where the bookseller is was redeveloped in 1921  - so before then.

Date:  1921-1922 
Nature:  New bank on corner site.   Classical.  Contractor: G. & T. Crampton.

comment.author: 26640250@N02
comment._content:
I think I have it solved.
View the image in Light Box, that's the magnifying glass between the 'Newer' & 'Older' buttons above the image, then select the biggest size (in this case 2000), then use the zoom facility in your browser.
Go real close on the base of the monument and you will see that the paving is still being installed, which to me means it is not yet officially unveiled (1911) or this part was not ready for the unveiling.
Is that proof enough ?

comment.author: 26640250@N02
comment._content: Sorry, forgot to mention there is a wreath hanging just under Parnell's feet too. Looks to me like the new monument is the reason this image was taken.

comment.author: 92133321@N03
comment._content:
I posted this on another forum looking at this photograph: Based on show times and the advertising of New Living Pictures, I'd say this is probably 1913 or 1914, probably even spring (from the tree and the clothing) 1913. James T. Jameson, who ran the Irish Animated Picture Company at the Rotunda - and film/variety shows in many other towns around the country - seems to have moved his advertising away from the phrase "Living Pictures," which was beginning to sound old fashioned, by early 1915.
I'll add now that I don't think this can be 1911 based on the showtimes. The season of Rotunda Pictures that ran from 4 September-11 November 1911 - which included a film of the Unveiling of the Parnell Monument by the Thursday (7 Oct)  following the unveiling - had continuous performances and not advertised times (3, 6.45, 9) as we see in the photograph. When another picture season began at the Rotunda on 18 December (it would run until 30  March 1912), it did have advertised times, but these were 3, 7 and 9. This is a small difference from 3, 6.45 and 9, but it is significant because, as we can see, it would have involved complete redoing the signs at the front of the Rotunda. That change of signs came for a season that began in late December 1912. 
So, I speculate (and only that) that we are looking at a photograph taken almost exactly a century ago in early 1913.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/denis-condon] Hello Denis, and very convincing speculation it is too! Thank you very much, and I'm amending the date on this one pending any further information...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
